'Perfluorobutanesulfonic acid' ('PFBS') is a chemical compound with a four
carbon fluorocarbon chain and a sulfonic acid functional group. As an anion it
functions as a stable fluorosurfactant because of the strength of
carbonâfluorine bonds.

PFBS has served as a replacement for the persistent, toxic, and bioaccumulative
perfluorooctanesulfonic acid (PFOS) in 3M's Scotchgard stain repellents since
June 2003. PFBS has a much shorter half-life in
people than PFOS (a little over one month vs. 5.4 years). While PFBS is expected to be persistent in the
environment, multiple studies (that are not referenced in following
reference[5]) claim that PFBS is neither toxic nor bioaccumulative.

3M markets surfactant with PFBS in two fluorosurfactants.
